bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to A.R. Hufford, October 2, 1940

div1.p: Hench thanks Hufford for his help regarding the Dean Bridge.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to A.R. Hufford, October 2, 1940
div1.opener:
October 2, 1940
Dr. A. R. Hufford
505 Medical Arts Building
Grand Rapids, Michigan
My dear Doctor Hufford:
div1.p:
Thank you very much indeed for your
help in the matter of the Dean Bridge. It is most useful.
I have received the photographs, and they are just what I
wanted.

We have been using gold (Myochrysine--
Merck) for three or four years in the hospital, in certain
selected cases. We have had no miracles and are somewhat dis-
appointed with it. Nevertheless, we continue to use it. Did
you see our last Rheumatism Review, Annals of Internal Medicine,
March and April, 1940? This carries a complete review of the
matter. I am finishing the next Review and the year's dope is
about as it was last year. About 5 per cent of patients are
cured, about 30 per cent are notably improved. Whether that
is worth the risk or not, I do not know, but I suspect that
it is. We have had no serious reactions, but these are always
possible. Neither we nor others have much faith that the
vitamins can prevent these reactions.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
